T cells

Nature Immunology volume 26, page 1839 (2025)Cite this article

Subjects

T cell exhaustion involves reduced functionality that can underlie failure of tumor immunity or immunotherapy. Data now published in Nature show that a specific type of proteotoxic stress response (PSR) exerts control over this state. The authors induced T cell exhaustion in vitro by chronic T cell receptor stimulation, in mice by chronic lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection (clone 13), or with tumor models, and found discordance between protein and mRNA expression profiles. Stress granules, misfolded protein aggregates and protein catabolism were a feature of exhaustion. This PSR seems to be distinct from conventional forms of unfolded protein and integrated stress responses, as it involves an increase in overall translation and activity of specific chaperone molecules that show promise as targets for immunotherapy to reduce exhaustion. The data indicate that this distinct PSR is causative of T cell exhaustion, as chemical or genetic induction of misfolded proteins had this effect on effector T cells even in the absence of chronic T cell receptor activation. The authors also show that AKT signaling is an upstream effector of this PSR. Together these data identify proteostatic control over T cell function and point to possible strategies to boost immunotherapy.
